articles.headline: Disney Puts Tickets on a Facebook Site
articles.snippet: With an application for “Toy Story 3”, the company puts moviegoers in touch with tickets and friends at the same time.
articles.abstract: With an application for “Toy Story 3”, the company puts moviegoers in touch with tickets and friends at the same time.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company has created what it believes is a first-of-its-kind application allowing Facebook users to buy tickets to “Toy Story 3” without leaving the social networking site and while, at the same time, prodding their friends to come along.

articles.headline: Jobs Bill vs. Deficit, a Showdown in the Senate
articles.snippet: Lawmakers will have to consider the impact on the deficit of $200 billion legislation to create jobs.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers will have to consider the impact on the deficit of $200 billion legislation to create jobs.

articles.headline: Spain Struggles to Agree on a Path to Recovery
articles.snippet: Public resistance to austerity makes it hard for the Spanish government to keep a grip on power.
articles.abstract: Public resistance to austerity makes it hard for the Spanish government to keep a grip on power.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID  Caught between a populace resistant to more austerity measures and investors demanding budget cuts and more flexible labor markets, the Spanish government is finding it increasingly difficult to keep a grip on power.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Japan’s Premier Will Quit as Approval Plummets
articles.snippet: Yukio Hatoyama’s support faltered after he went back on pledges to remove a U.S. base from Okinawa.
articles.abstract: Yukio Hatoyama’s support faltered after he went back on pledges to remove a U.S. base from Okinawa.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea  Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama of Japan, who swept into power last year with bold promises to revamp the country, then faltered over broken campaign pledges to remove an American base from Okinawa, announced Wednesday that he would step down.

articles.headline: Turkish Funds Helped Group Test Blockade
articles.snippet: When the Free Gaza Movement teamed up with a much wealthier Turkish organization to assemble a flotilla, Israel began to see it as a serious threat.
articles.abstract: When the Free Gaza Movement teamed up with a much wealthier Turkish organization to assemble a flotilla, Israel began to see it as a serious threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Since 2007, a small group of hard-core activists has repeatedly tried to sail cargo-laden ships into Gaza in an effort to thwart Israel’s blockade. But when the Free Gaza Movement teamed up with a much wealthier Turkish organization to assemble a flotilla, it became more than a nuisance, supercharged by the group’s money, manpower and symbolic resonance into what Israel sees as a serious and growing threat.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Michael Slackman

articles.headline: Videos Carry On the Fight Over Sea Raid
articles.snippet: What is missing so far from flotilla clips on both sides is context: it is difficult to say who attacked first.
articles.abstract: What is missing so far from flotilla clips on both sides is context: it is difficult to say who attacked first.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Israeli commandos attacked the so-called Freedom Flotilla, both sides were well armed — with video cameras — and both sides have released a blizzard of video clips as evidence that the other side was the aggressor in the conflict on Monday, which left nine activists dead.

articles.headline: Big Setback for A.I.G. in Repaying Taxpayers
articles.snippet: With Prudential no longer involved, A.I.G. has no obvious suitor and may sell its prized Asian subsidiary in an initial offering.
articles.abstract: With Prudential no longer involved, A.I.G. has no obvious suitor and may sell its prized Asian subsidiary in an initial offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group scuttled the deal to sell its huge Asian life insurance arm to Prudential of Britain for about $35 billion, in a major setback to repaying the government for its 2008 rescue.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Seek to Bar Wall St. Financier
articles.snippet: Steven L. Rattner has resisted the government’s effort to keep him from working during a kickback investigation.
articles.abstract: Steven L. Rattner has resisted the government’s effort to keep him from working during a kickback investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it investigates a suspected kickback scheme in New York’s pension system, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been pushing to bar Steven L. Rattner, a prominent financier and former adviser to the Obama administration on the auto industry, from working in the securities industry for up to three years, according to three people told of the discussions.

articles.headline: Questions for Moody’s and Buffett
articles.snippet: At a hearing, the billionaire said he did not know much about the credit rating market, though his company is the largest shareholder in Moody’s.
articles.abstract: At a hearing, the billionaire said he did not know much about the credit rating market, though his company is the largest shareholder in Moody’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to investing, stick with what you know.
